it to be better than The Great War, you’d expect atleast some sort of redemption from the producers.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Let’s break it down:</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Varys betrays Dany and she burns him alive - and Jon and Tyrion witness it first hand and still go into battle. And when she goes all Mad Queen they’re still surprised?</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I still can’t believe the steep character shift they brought about for Dany either. time around. Just a few more thoughts on one major arc (spoilers), then quick takes and Reddit highlights.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>#1: “And the end of that way is death.”</b></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">There are many ways in which Game of Thrones (and perhaps ASOIAF itself) <i>isn’t</i> a classic greek tragedy. But there’s one rather conspicuous way in which it is, which I think the showrunners deserve some credit for committing to.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">If we were paying attention, Dany’s heel-turn, though overly sudden, wasn’t quite a turn. Her fate was mechanical — the necessary outcome of her fatal flaw meeting an environment s...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_w7GIVvEW19_more"><span I would have previously rejected something so loaded but … I think she’s earned it? Honestly, I don’t want to hear another goddamn fucking <i>word </i>about Dany’s benevolence, her good intentions, her birthright, her abolitionist wanderings, or anything. If you want to delude yourself into thinking GRRM doesn’t have something <i>pretty ...</i></li></ul></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wlsxbvZ523_more"><span id="__w2_wX9k6WhK9_answer_content"><div id="wX9k6WhK13"><div class="Expandable Toggle AnswerExpandable SimpleToggle AnswerExpandableOneState" id="__w2_wX9k6WhK14__truncated"><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="wX9k6WhK24"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">It was extremely fun to watch but I was disappointed at lots of ways.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>Varys-</b></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">We all knew he’d die this way, if he ever dies. I’m disappointed at Tyrion’s actions. Varys saved from his trial. I’d expect better from Tyrion.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">But Varys played the game. He wrote the first later at day, when Jon arrived. He probably sent the first Letter long ago from his execution. We will see a pay-off of it.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>Tyrion- </b>He realized Varys was right. I loved what he did for Jamie. Makes sense. I also loved his effort to save the innocent. Dany wasted it, sadly.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>Battle- </b>No Golden Company fight Scene?! Really? Drogon burni...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wX9k6WhK23_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" id="__w2_wX9k6WhK23_loading"><span class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">The first thing we have to recognize you guys is that Dany had no choice but to murder women and children. Sansa made her do it. I like this excuse, I shall use it for myself from now on. “Officer, I know I was speeding, but this is a victory for Sansa.” Sorry, I am never <i>not</i> going to laugh about that line.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Dany went dark fast this episode, and I would love to relish that she is indeed the big bad at last, but, honestly, that wasn’t even fun for me. I mean, theoretically, the alternate version that played in my head, <i>that</i> was nice, whatever it was we saw on the screen, a little less so. class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">GoT is dead, and I can point to the exact moment which killed it. It died here, at the Battle of the Bastards:</p><div class="ui_qtext_image_outer"><div class="ui_qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape ui_qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-50311c8c94c990605fa1426ffefeddda" master_src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-abc1c0d9643630597604ba775727d4a1-c" master_w="1920" master_h="835"></div></div><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">And here’s the thing. I loved the Battle of the Bastards (despite the abysmal military tactics). The problem isn’t with that episode itself. The problem is what they did to the showrunners.</p><hr class="qtext_hr"><blockquote><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b><i>The GoT producers now believe GoT is all about SFX.</i></b></p></blockquote><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">They think the people watch the show for the “realistic” battle sequences.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">But it isn’t. It never has been. Let’s rewind the clock waaaayyyy back. All the way to Season 1. Let’s look at the very first battle scene ever depicted in the show:</p><div class="ui_qtext_image_outer"><div class="ui_qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape ui_qtext_image zoomable_in class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><i>Nothing else matters. Only us. </i>Jaime Lannister</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>Spoilers for Episode 5 (Recap/Review)</b></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Episode 5 was much better than “The Last of the Starks.” The showrunners wanted to bring everything together in this episode.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">The bad news— that isn’t a high bar. This was a busy episode and very upsetting. I now do understand what GRRM means when he says that the showrunners will arrive at a similar ending. However, whatever we will get from the show will feel incomplete, even when we call it the end.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>Daenerys Lost Her Mind, But Why?</b> I expected class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>Ashes to Ashes</b></p><div class="ui_qtext_image_outer"><div class="ui_qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape ui_qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-aa22e829ddf067bd8553e09aaccf6abc" master_src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-5c2ab978a5179cdcd843ceca3123148f" master_w="1920" master_h="1080"></div></div><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">King’s Landing is dead, long live King’s Landing. Dany unleashing her inner Targaryen and turning the once resplendent capital of the Seven Kingdoms into the world’s largest KFC order was harrowing and horrifying yet entirely in tune with her character. She always has been a dormant volcano kept in check by those near and dear to her, and now that she has neither, well,<i> Vesuvius ain’t got shit on her.</i></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Yes, it was rushed and ill-executed, but the seeds were there. If only they had taken more time and allowed the turn to feel more organic.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">She is now officially the big bad of Game...</p></span><a class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="w9rzl3D620"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">My god.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">They did some characters dirty.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Lets start off with Danerys Targyean.</p><div class="ui_qtext_image_outer"><div class="ui_qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="portrait ui_qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-a74a0b2a5574818132b696c5b3497cd6" master_src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-0340d1983103bd3441ee4fdd21b4afb7" master_w="634" master_h="872"></div></div><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Daenerys Targyean, in my opinion, WAS a tragic hero.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Sure, she was annoying, but she wasn’t evil. She killed people who refused to bend the knee, but she had reasons to. She was annoying, but she was a good guy and not that bad of a character.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I do understand why Danerys Targayean turn Mad Queen, and I can’t blame her.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">She lost two dragons who were like children, she lost her best friend, her guardian who was in the friend zone, her Hand failed her multiple times, Varys betrayed her, and her nephew won’t bang her.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">So yes...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_w9rzl3D619_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" id="__w2_w9rzl3D619_loading"><span class="loading">Loading…</span></span></div></div></div></div><div class="Toggle SimpleToggle AnswerExpandableOneState Expandable AnswerExpandable hidden" id="__w2_w9rzl3D614__expanded"></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="pagedlist_item" fought Dany), so I wasn’t into it. The cinematography was great as usual, but I didn’t like the way certain characters died.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">My reactions to some of the scenes:</p><ol><li>Just about every major Quora user here knew Varys would burn. class="AnswerExpandable AnswerExpandableOneState SimpleToggle Expandable Toggle" id="__w2_wAUj1vRO14__truncated"><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="wAUj1vRO20"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">This answer might get lost faster than a Daenerys opponent in the flames of Drogon’s breath but I shall give my insight.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">SPOILERS. Obviously.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">My sentiments can be summed up perfectly with this:</p><div class="ui_qtext_image_outer"><div class="ui_qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape ui_qtext_image zoomable_in_feed" src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-1219d3fd874643fc698202a7c0a302ee" master_src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-1219d3fd874643fc698202a7c0a302ee" master_w="321" master_h="320"></div></div><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I am beyond disappointed. To some degree, it was not a surprise. Here’s everything wrong with Game Of Thrones Season 8 Episode 5.</p><ul><li><b>Forced, and stupid, Mad Queen narrative.</b></li></ul><div class="ui_qtext_image_outer"><div class="ui_qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape ui_qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-7d17f175aeab71d2c09d43abf32dee05" master_src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-f4cc981ff3c6a2b740ec0e770e84b130" master_w="606" master_h="506"></div></div><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">So, Euron’s fleet is ambushed, Cersei’s remaining army and the citizens of the Red Keep surrender, ringing the city’s bell. As the peacemaker and tyrant hater/destroyer Daenerys was made to be since the beginning of her efforts to...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wAUj1vRO19_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" id="__w2_wAUj1vRO19_loading"><span class="loading">Loading…</span></span></div></div></div></div><div class="AnswerExpandable He was pretty much a goner when he decided to act last episode and the show pulls no punches in his execution. Thing is, as I and many others had predicted, the letter he burns before his arrest isn’t the same one that he’s writing at the beginning of the episode. He sent out a bunch of them and only the final one was left unsent. Daenerys will discover this to her deepening madness as news of the slaughter she propagated spreads along with the news that there’s a better heir in town. class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>Spoilers for Season 8 Episode 5.</b></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">This episode has set the stage for the final confrontation in the epic TV series that defined the decade, and possibly will be a benchmark for fantasy depictions in the decades that follow. As such, therefore, it already had a huge burden to share. This episode was not able to shoulder the insurmountable expectations that were inevitable, and now I understand GRRM’s dilemma. This cannot end well for everybody, folks. So, before you ask for more books, make sure you’re ready for it.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Anyway, kudos to the cinematography, camerawork, acting and choreography as class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="wGPrtgbi20"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I just finished watching it, here are my thoughts:</p><ul><li>We have Varys recycle some quotes from earlier on.</li><li>Varys is technically right; Daenerys shouldn’t become queen. But, if you look at things from Daenerys’ perspective, she was being betrayed by one of her advisors. Sentencing him to death was the right thing to do if she wished to keep her head. I don’t think what she did to him was particularly evil; I understand why she did it. The only evil thing about it was the manner in which he was executed.</li><li>I don’t get why Tyrion ratted out Varys though.</li><li>Tyrion breaking Jaime out is a throwback to Jaime ...</li></ul></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wGPrtgbi19_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" id="__w2_wGPrtgbi19_loading"><span class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Because we have been robbed of really satisfying writing for Tyrion and Jon’s characters — the Three Heads of the Story, if not the Dragon — the only tragic hero left from GRRM’s tale is Daenerys, pushed into her position by a trio of betrayals and a rejection from a lover. Jon is just a conventional hero; Tyrion is…well, basically a supporting role.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">(All this is very hastily sketched out by the writers; the line from plot point A to point B is made of the flimsiest of spider threads at this point: but it is there.)</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I could dwell on the negative and cry out once again what have these doofuses...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_whvTWE1E19_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" long-awaited episodes of <i>Game of Thrones</i>. It’s been pretty obvious for a couple of seasons that we were going to have a battle take place in King’s Landing, and it’s finally here. I’m not going to write extensively over the writing or the production, because that’s already been covered quite a lot in this thread anyway. Instead, I’m going to briefly mention it, and then take a look at the symbolism.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Before we continue, let me remind everybody:</p><div background-url="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-801d3dc7534f5ab896af708bf43d2577" gif-embedded="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-801d3dc7534f5ab896af708bf43d2577" is-playing="true" data-interactive="true" class="ui_qtext_gif_noclick_wrapper"><img src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-801d3dc7534f5ab896af708bf43d2577" class="ui_qtext_image" style="max-width: 100%;"></div><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Let us begin. New, as they get to benefit from the talent of Miguel Sapochnik. The visuals were stunning, particularly when Drogon went full on beastmode on King’s Landing.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">But I’m afraid this episode confirmed a lot of our fears from the last 2 episodes, meaning that if we were going to find any enjoyment at all at the ending of our beloved show, we were going to have to do some serious mental gymnastics to suspend all our disbeliefs, as well as our emotional investment in our characters.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Here are some moments I liked and disliked:</p><ul><li>I found the whole Nice moment with Arya, and I expected that he wouldn’t make it out alive. Ah well, the chickens of Westeros are safe.</li><li>Erm, that’s about it…</li></ul><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>Things I Didn’t Like</b></p><ul><li>Show Jon is so dumb. class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="wA5j0Ua320"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I have thoroughly enjoyed this season of <i>Game of Thrones</i>, until this episode.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I’m not going to lie, I <i>fucking hated</i> this episode. Hated it.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Now, I, like <span class="qlink_container"><a href="/profile/Kelsey-L-Hayes">Kelsey L. Hayes</a></span>, have long known that <i>something</i> like this was coming with Dany. I never bought into the She-Ra, girl-power accolades people were happy to throw on her. I have long expected that she would use her Dragon to torch King’s Landing and/or the Red Keep in <i>some</i> way, and I fully expect that we will see something similar in the books (if they ever fucking get finished!), but the context in which it happened in the show pissed me right ...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wA5j0Ua319_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" id="__w2_wA5j0Ua319_loading"><span class="loading">Loading…</span></span></div></div></div></div><div class="AnswerExpandableOneState SimpleToggle AnswerExpandable Expandable Toggle hidden" id="__w2_wA5j0Ua314__expanded"></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="pagedlist_item" id="wHI31AmP1"></div><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="wVP57OX820"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">"<b>A Targaryen alone in the world is a terrible thing.</b>"</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Well, we can't say we weren't warned, and by another Targaryen, no less.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I'm not a book partisan, and never have been. And yet, in the wake of this episode, I keep thinking back to one thing from the books that I wish D&amp;D had worked into the show, if not in this episode, than at least at some point in the past.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">In her chapters in A Song of Ice and Fire, Daenerys often thinks back to "the house with the red door." This was a large home in the Free City of Braavos where she lived with her brother Viserys and their protector, Ser Willem Darry....</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" descended on King’s Landing. It was pure devastation. This was a massacre, just wholesale violence for the sake of violence. If viewers thought that things could end peacefully between the Red Keep, the Mother of Dragons, and anyone unlucky enough to be caught between them, this episode proved that’s never going to happen.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">“The Bells” also reminded us that sometimes <i>Game of Thrones </i>doesn’t make sense. If you, like me, watch <i>Game of Thrones </i>with Twitter running in the background, there’s a good chance you noticed that almost everyone responding to the show was angry. best episode of the season so far – interesting, exciting, thought-provoking.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">However, it was not sufficient to redeem the season and compensate all the logical fallacies, inconsistensies and plot holes. In fact, to an extent, it made the weak-writing/Holywoodish approach even more pronounced.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Here are some of my thoughts:</p><ul><li>The way they handled Varys death was fairly anticlimactic. He kinda went down in similar fashion as Littlefinger in a sense that his treason was too noble and… obvious. I think it is out of his character to throw caution to the winds and risk so much for...</li></ul></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wbN73cma19_more"><span Fear"</b> - four words and Dany's transformation from a heroine to a villain was complete.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Michele Clapton gave a big hint, before the season 8 started, in regard to the color choice for Dany's costumes and their significance. As the red would seep through her white, it would mean that she is accepting her Targaryen side more and more. This episode, she was all red, and she went full "fire and blood" on King's Landing.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">The show could have made for a chilling last scene if Arya would have whispered "Queen Daenerys" before she rode on our horse.</p><hr class="qtext_hr"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Character Review:</p><ul><li><b>Dany </b>- She was quite is lacking: the Geneva Convention and s'mores.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">My review of this episode is the same as the last few… the core issue is pacing, but it leads to story problems because people have to make dumb choices inconsistent with their characters to make the Thing happen. Many of these story choices would work if the battle for King’s Landing was the focus of an entire season and things could slow-boil; when they’re rushed, they get contrived and annoying.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Tyrion's transformation into the Dumbest Man In Westeros (non-Jon-Snow division) is now complete. class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><ul><li>Was Varys’ little bird attempting to poison Daenerys? Is that why she reported that Daenerys wasn't eating her food, and why she was showing concern about the guards taking notice of her?</li><li>Tyrion's fear of Daenerys was palpable during their private talk. He stammered a lot, allowed her to talk over him, and avoided eye contact, while Daenerys was behaving very much like Stannis after he lost the Battle of the Blackwater.</li><li>Tyrion snitching on Varys was a shame.</li><li>I wonder why Varys took his rings off before his execution? Did he leave them as payment for his little birds perhaps?</li><li>Was Jon looking at ...</li></ul></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wqkRCFqE19_more"><span class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">“And I looked, and behold a pale horse: and his name that sat on him was Death, and Hell followed with him.”</p><div class="ui_qtext_image_outer"><div class="ui_qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape ui_qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-2d2a0714bc7ed0c7049a7727aeb8d216" you desire slips through your fingers, when your closest friends perish and your most trusted advisors betray you, when your children are slaughtered and your lover rejects your advances, how can anything remain but fear and hatred?</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Dany, you have all the power in the world. The power of life and death, the medieval Atom Bomb. I love you, but alas, you have gone down the path of madness. You’ve given in to your innermost human tendencies - revenge, fear, death. Y...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wQKXTRMK19_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" id="__w2_wQKXTRMK19_loading"><span id="__w2_wZJcTFA512_follow_button_section"><div class="u-relative icon_follow_button_wrapper"><div class="u-absolute u-absolute--center u-border-radius--ellipse u-padding-right--xs u-padding-left--xs id="__w2_wZJcTFA59_answer_content"><div id="wZJcTFA513"><div class="AnswerExpandableOneState AnswerExpandable Toggle SimpleToggle Expandable" id="__w2_wZJcTFA514__truncated"><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="wZJcTFA520"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">After the crapbag that was episode four and the misfire that was episode three, I expected I’d hate this one, but I fucking loved it. Sure, there were idiotic moments (Euron’s fight) and idiotic characters (Tyrion, Jon, and Jaime, in particular), but this episode perfected Dany, and that’s all I wanted.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">To be painfully clear: Dany is <i>not</i> the villain; she’s the tragic hero.* This episode finally stuck the landing on that core aspect of her character. Of course Dany would burn it all down. Was it justifiable? No! Was it understandable? Yes! "Let it be fear." It's all she has; she knows it, and...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wZJcTFA519_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" episode! I was surprised about what Daenerys did.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">These things really stood out to me:</p><ul><li><b>Daenerys burned down the whole city</b>. Wow, I am speechless. It was a true horror. I mean, once she got started on her second run, after the surrender bells started, she just kept going, burning and burning, everything, people, civilians, children. If this isn’t full-on Mad Queen, I don’t know what is.</li><li><b>Varys’ death because of Tyrion ratting him out</b>. I was stunned that Tyrion did that. Did he really think that Varys hadn’t already let the cat out of the bag? I tend to think he’s already let other...</li></ul></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wiaRxjSV19_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" id="__w2_wK80LAb812_follow_button_section"><div class="u-relative icon_follow_button_wrapper"><div class="u-absolute u-absolute--center u-border-radius--ellipse u-padding-right--xs u-padding-left--xs icon_follow_button" id="__w2_wK80LAb812_follow_button"><span id="wK80LAb827"></span></div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="__w2_wK80LAb829_suggested_section"></div></div></div><div id="__w2_wK80LAb89_answer_content"><div id="wK80LAb813"><div class="AnswerExpandableOneState Expandable AnswerExpandable SimpleToggle Toggle" id="__w2_wK80LAb814__truncated"><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="wK80LAb820"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Some observations on S8E5:</p><ul><li>Tyrion and Varys have been wasted this season. They are way too good to be sitting on the bench as much as they have.</li><li>None of the scorpions on the walls had any spears to reload.</li><li>“The Golden Company” should rename themselves “The Golden Brown Company”.</li><li>Jaime’s battle with Euron was pointless. It had no impact on Jaime’s actions, it had no impact on the plot. Captain should have gone down with his ship(s).</li><li>The bell tower that everyone was watching didn’t have a seven pointed star. Looked Christian.</li><li>Dany hasn’t eaten in a few days. review, I want to tell you a story although it's familiar to most of you.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">A story of someone who was nothing at the beginning. Someone whose family has been rooted out of the throne before season 1. Let's not go in too much of details but all of us know that the person did not have an easy past. So now, the person has a miraculous incident which brings her three dragons and suddenly everyone around her starts believing she can acquire the throne back from the usurpers and take back what has been told to her by everyone around her.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">So she wholeheartedly accepts the challenge...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" As if Episode 3 was not bad enough, now this!</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">As a writer, I think they committed a cardinal sin by using a <span class="qlink_container"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deus_ex_machina" rel="noopener nofollow" target="_blank" onclick="return Q.openUrl(this, 140884512);" class="external_link" data-qt-tooltip="wikipedia.org">Deus ex machina</a></span> plot device to resolve a hopeless situation. Let’s face it, the odds of taking Red Keep were extremely low without the queen-goddess and her dragon. They would have had a hard time getting into the city alone, being pelted with archers and scorpions from the walls. Why was the defending army OUTSIDE the main gate in the first place?</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">It took one shot to kill a drag...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" Like GRRM said, they needed a few more seasons.</p><ul><li>Varys: the illustrious spymaster was always for the people, afterall. And stupid one at that. Taking to Jon in the open like that. Who was he writing to? The Citadel? Dorne? … Varysmallow was set up from two seasons ago: both Dany and Varys kept their end of the bargain. Varys told her she was nuts, and Dany burned him.</li><li>Euron: after all, all he wanted to do was to fuck a queen. Did nothing either ways.</li><li>Davos: what did he smuggle? The boat for Jaime?</li><li>Tyrion: he rats Varys to the queen and betrays the queen to save Cersei and J...</li></ul></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wQrr8piX19_more"><span awesome to watch, if you just sit back and don’t think too much about it all.”</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Yes, this episode was spectacular to watch, truly awesome, like the Long Night its one of the most impressive things ever made for TV.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">The problem is that Game of Thrones grew and flourished as a series that was both awesome to watch and something you could think about.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">The gritty, nerve tangling awesomeness of this episode was nearly as thrilling as “The Long Night”, it came close but episode 3 was the better of the two. The aerial scenes over Kingslanding were awesome a...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wOZsTiIB19_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" have been waay longer. It seems like D&amp;D have an end in mind, and they have a constraint of 6 episodes, and they have worked backwards from that end to plan out each episode. As a result, a lot of character development seems a little rushed. That's the problem with the entire season, innit? And That's the problem with this episode.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>Dany turned into the Mad Queen. </b>I guess that was one ending that a lot of people were predicting, and a lot of people were expecting. I think it would have worked a lot better if there was more time spent on it. season 8 reminds me of Harvey Dent in Batman</p><div class="ui_qtext_image_outer"><div class="ui_qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape ui_qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" master_h="405"></div></div><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">The brilliance of word-smithing, character creation and plots that were a characteristic of the first four seasons, till the show closely followed the books was what made the series a hit. It has been going steadily downhill since then what with asinine plots, uncharacteristic stances taken by key figures. <i>For the plot is silly and full of errors.</i></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">In season 8, the show-runners have decided to take it to another level. The suspense was good, I felt sick and the music was utterly brilliant. Yet there’s more wrong than right with this one. With every episode this season, it was rushed. Yet, everyone can already agree on that so here are my thoughts. All opinated, but think about the logic.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">• Jon’s a bit stupid but he’s great fighter. I wanted to see that!!! He didn’t contribute much in episode 3 so I had hoped he’d have some good screen time, but apparently not.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">• Arya had too much screen time for me. She’s cool and everything, but instead of her walking past all he people dying, make it J...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wpXf6q9J19_more"><span Nope, she just burned them all because why? They didn’t fall on their knees worshipping her? She’s completely mad, no turning back from this.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I don’t understand why Tyrion told Dany about Varys. To earn Dany’s favor? id="__w2_wNE6mPmd9_answer_content"><div id="wNE6mPmd13"><div class="Toggle Expandable AnswerExpandableOneState SimpleToggle AnswerExpandable" id="__w2_wNE6mPmd14__truncated"><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="wNE6mPmd20"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I feel…conflicted about this episode. On the one hand, it’s definitely better than episode 4. I certainly liked it more than most people seem to have. But there were things that didn’t make sense in this episode as well.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>What I liked</b></p><ul><li>Tyrion and Jaime’s goodbye. That was a genuinely touching scene.</li><li>CleganeBowl and the goodbye between Sandor and Arya.</li></ul><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>What I didn’t like</b></p><ul><li>Jaime’s disappointing arc. Seasons of development went right out the window. I was really hoping he would be the one to take out Cersei, even if the show did not reference the Valonqar Prophecy by Maggi the Frog.</li></ul><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>What I feel conflic...</b></p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wNE6mPmd19_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" fact i have alerts to Kelsey L. Hayes comments. They always make me laugh and are deeply insightful.<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;However, i would invite us to look at GRRM's whole work from another point of view.<br>&nbsp;A Song of Ice and Fire is a commentary on history and its lessons.<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;As a Nigerian, i couldn't help drawing parallels to the Targayens' initial colonialism of Westeros and the British colonialism of Nigeria or USA.<br>&nbsp;(Coincidentally, both Nigeria and USA have had very costly post - independence Civil Wars when parts of their r...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" the Rain</i></b></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Whether the events of this episode seem logical depends on how one views the equation between Dany and Missandei. Were Facebook to document their “equals in a hierarchy” relationship, the highlight reel would likely feature such delights as Missandei’s instantly meme-worthy “all <i>men</i> must die; we are not men” and a gif of the two holding hands in the fighting pits, defiant in the face of death. class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><blockquote><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><i>Then he turned to his pyromancer, "Burn them all," he said. "Burn them in their homes, burn them in their beds." - Jaime V, A Storm of Swords, ASOIAF III</i></p></blockquote><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Twenty five years later, it came into fruition. Not by him, but by his blood. Not with the help of the nasty old pyromancers, but with a bloody dragon. Aerys II Targaryen thought that he himself could turn into a fire-breathing monster and burn them all. Instead, his daughter burnt them all to a crisp <i>with</i> a fire-breathing monster. Hell rought upon the capital of Westeros. Fire and Blood descended upon King’s Landing. And everything burned....</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wsFurR4H19_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" id="__w2_wsFurR4H19_loading"><span class="ui_layout_photo_text u-flex ui_layout_size--small"><div class="ui_layout_photo_wrapper u-flex-none"><div class="ui_layout_photo u-relative"><div class="u-flex-inline" id="wxWjg1aV23"><div class="hover_menu hidden show_nub" id="__w2_wxWjg1aV34_menu"><div class="hover_menu_contents" id="__w2_wxWjg1aV34_menu_contents"> </div></div><span class="photo_tooltip u-inline" class="feed_item_answer_user"><span id="wxWjg1aV25"><span id="wxWjg1aV30"><div class="hover_menu hidden white_bg show_nub" id="__w2_wxWjg1aV31_menu"><div class="hover_menu_contents" id="__w2_wxWjg1aV31_menu_contents"> </div></div><span id="__w2_wxWjg1aV31_link"><a class="user" href="/profile/William-Himes" action_mousedown="UserLinkClickthrough" id="__w2_wxWjg1aV31_name_link">William Himes</a></span></span><span class="NameCredential">, studied at University of Richmond School of Law</span></span></div><span class="credibility_wrapper"><div class="AnswerCredibilityFacts CredibilityFacts pass_color_to_child_links"><span id="wxWjg1aV32"><a class="answer_permalink" action_mousedown="AnswerPermalinkClickthrough" href="/What-is-your-review-of-Game-Of-Thrones-S8E5-2/answer/William-Himes" rel="nofollow" id="__w2_wxWjg1aV33_link">Answered May 13, 2019</a></span><span class="bullet"> · </span>Author has <span class="bold_num">1.3k</span> answers and <span class="bold_num">1.3m</span> answer views</div></span></div><div class="hidden" id="__w2_wxWjg1aV12_follow_button_section"><div class="u-relative icon_follow_button_wrapper"><div class="u-absolute u-absolute--center u-border-radius--ellipse u-padding-right--xs u-padding-left--xs icon_follow_button" id="__w2_wxWjg1aV12_follow_button"><span id="wxWjg1aV27"></span></div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="__w2_wxWjg1aV29_suggested_section"></div></div></div><div id="__w2_wxWjg1aV9_answer_content"><div id="wxWjg1aV13"><div class="SimpleToggle AnswerExpandableOneState Expandable Toggle AnswerExpandable" id="__w2_wxWjg1aV14__truncated"><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="wxWjg1aV20"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">So we all knew where this was headed, basically. Dany isolated and angry, Jon becoming disillusioned, Tyrion still holding out hope that he could save the world. We all knew it culminated in the City of King’s Landing in flame, innocent and guilty alike burning alive or crushed in the wreckage.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">The interesting part, the part we tuned in today to see, was how we got there. What was the last straw? What would believably push Daenerys off the edge.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">It turns out that she, like the late Lord Varys, really doesn’t care much for bells. class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">A beautiful death.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Have you ever seen somebody you love do something you wish they didn’t? Did it take you by surprise? Or was it just a confirmation of who they’ve always been? Does it matter? You still stand by and watch and even if you could intervene, it wouldn’t stop them. People are like that. <i>Game of Thrones</i> is like that too. It was when Ned told Cersei to run, when Robb wed Talisa, when Oberyn asked for a confession and it is now that Daenerys is burning King’s Landing. All you can do is watch and wish it wasn’t happening.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">But unlike real life, where often we’re left scrambling for cl...</p></span><a disappointment. Everywhere I could see that the creators of the show are too conscious about the audience getting it right. They simply over thought about which part they would crack it. Some times you should give what the audience wants. Let them be right. After all, it is GameOfThrones and there are chances that, people would feel happy about being right.</p><div class="ui_qtext_image_outer"><div class="ui_qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape ui_qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-e792af8f6aac693fc04bd84917b6b261" master_src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-5dc494b6fae4aa8f6eb54a75b752749e" master_w="3733" master_h="2100"></div></div><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><i>Source: Google Images</i></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>So what I liked in S8 x E5?</b></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Tyrion's emotional variance. Qybrun deserved to die by his creation. We finally get Cleganebowl, Sandor’s trajectory was to end his brother.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Cersei and Jamie dying together was fitting. Now the worst happened after Lannisters were convinced to surrender (by another Lannister) to Targayen.</i></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Prior to the sack in Robert’s time, Ned Stark was best buds with Robert, the one trying to be king. href="/What-is-your-review-of-Game-Of-Thrones-S8E5-2/answer/Basil-Ahmad-7" rel="nofollow" id="__w2_wzs1jZx733_link">Answered May 12, 2019</a></span></div></span></div><div class="hidden" id="__w2_wzs1jZx714_follow_button_section"><div class="u-relative icon_follow_button_wrapper"><div class="u-absolute u-absolute--center u-border-radius--ellipse u-padding-right--xs u-padding-left--xs icon_follow_button" id="__w2_wzs1jZx714_follow_button"><span id="wzs1jZx727"></span></div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="__w2_wzs1jZx729_suggested_section"></div></div></div><div id="__w2_wzs1jZx79_answer_content"><div id="wzs1jZx710"><div class="Toggle AnswerExpandable Expandable AnswerExpandableOneState SimpleToggle" id="__w2_wzs1jZx711__truncated"><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="wzs1jZx720"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I really loved the mirroring between Arya’s POV in this episode and her POV when Ned Stark got beheaded. She’s seen her family die. She’s forced from every place she’s ever known as home. She gives up everything to become an assassin to get revenge, and for what? To repeat the same exact traumatic experience of being powerless, unable to help people or kill the people who hurt her. I could see a version of this playing out in the books to emphasize how pursuing vengeance won’t heal old wounds, and will probably end up creating new ones. She’s the best part of the episode for me.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">The futility...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wzs1jZx719_more"><span class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">It kind of makes perfect sense:</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Cersei knew she had lost. She knew that her military options had run dry. Fighting guaranteed her death, perhaps, maybe… just maybe… she can get out of this if she surrendered?</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Dany, meanwhile, wanted revenge. She didn't just want the crown. She didn't just want a reputation, she wanted to be either loved, or feared. And, after Jon grew cold feet about "her only love," she chose fear.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">It kind of sucks to be this right. I expected Cersei to go down fighting like a good villain, but she just had to not be completely evil, God damnit.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">How does she have the audacity class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">It feels like D&amp;D got a bunch of notes, and one of them was Daenerys going crazy, and instead of setting it up in a season or two, they killed a few people close to her in the span of two episodes, and had her burn King’s Landing randomly. And no matter how much people try to justify it, it was random.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Daenerys had a habit of threatening her enemies since season 1. I’m not arguing against that. However, these people weren’t her enemies. I could buy her burning people in the way, but killing everyone after she’s won already is stupid. class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">2 thumbs up. Easily the best episode since S8E2. Most iconic visuals possibly of the entire show’s run, although I’d have liked to see more of Dany’s face as she mowed down the innocents. The flow is still quite spotty, but subtlety wasn’t that necessary for this episode.</p><ul><li>I thought Dany’s turn was pretty well done and shocking to behold. Even if you can claim you expected it, seeing it was another matter.</li><li>Dany is definitively the Mad Queen now. Her behavior before the battle was meant to signal flirtation with madness. The distortion of the Bells which proceeded her decision to nuke King’s La...</li></ul></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wl65QPA919_more"><span id="__w2_wgy23qmM9_answer_content"><div id="wgy23qmM10"><div class="SimpleToggle AnswerExpandable Toggle Expandable AnswerExpandableOneState" id="__w2_wgy23qmM11__truncated"><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="wgy23qmM20"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">The episode had only one intention. Portray Dany as a villian.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Why would Dany kill innocents when they clearly surrendered? Is any person that mad ? If she was mad , why would she agree otherwise to Tyrion before ?</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">They just want jon snow to end up on throne anyway possible and for that they need to get rid of Dany.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Why was arya strolling through kings landing for nothing ? Again the plot is to set up everything against dany. Somehow they wanted arya to realise dany is evil for burning city and make her all set for killing Dany.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">It's the worst season and each episode keeps turning worst than be...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wgy23qmM19_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" So I’m not sure how I feel about that.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">But let’s do a plot-based review:</p><ul><li>Varys starts writing letters and Tyrion narcs on him immediately. Varys can’t wait until Dany proves to be a bad ruler and Tyrion can’t wait to out Varys until Dany has proven to be a good ruler. So this was a game of who betrays whom first and Tyrion wins? Not sure why this needed to play out so early before the war with Cersei even began.</li><li>Dany asks Jon to be present for Varys’s execution but not for the battle plans. class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">It is what can be described as directorially stunning, yet character-wise, lacklustre.</p><div class="ui_qtext_image_outer"><div class="ui_qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape ui_qtext_image zoomable_in_feed" src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-b77f160184b9bfb44597373b9bfbe738" of the 8-season saga promised a lot primarily. It left us on the edge of our seats with Missandei's death in the Episode 4, seeing Danaerys storm away from King's Landing, the Mad Queen unraveling.</p><ul><li>The episode's first major event was Varys's burning, due to him betraying Danaerys by supporting Jon's claim. He had served his character arc, and was ready to die.</li><li>Tyrion goes to see his captive brother for the last time, and freeing him. It seemed a last desperate attempt on Tyrion's part...</li></ul></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wyMIOGQg19_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><i>“For my review might be dank, full of spoilers, and wishful thinking about Gendry or Jon Snow sitting on my face”…</i></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>10m</b> Dany finds out that Jon spilt the beans to Sansa who done told Tyrion, who then ratted him out to Varys: <i>The Queen is not amused.</i></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>14m</b> Varys gets roasted; it doesn’t appear that he got his missive off to whomever it was supposed to go to about “the rightful heir to the Iron Throne”; of course, there was that other one that he was working on when one of his little birds stopped by with the check-in on Dany. Perhaps it might have been targeted to nervous investors in Braavos…?</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>18...</b></p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wW7JqpNh19_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" id="__w2_wW7JqpNh19_loading"><span class="loading">Loading…</span></span></div></div></div></div><div </div></div><span class="photo_tooltip u-inline" id="__w2_wHEP3GWI34_link"><a class="u-flex-inline" href="/profile/Debika-Chowdhury"><span class="ui_avatar u-flex-inline ui_avatar--large icon_follow_button" id="__w2_wHEP3GWI14_follow_button"><span id="wHEP3GWI27"></span></div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="__w2_wHEP3GWI29_suggested_section"></div></div></div><div id="__w2_wHEP3GWI9_answer_content"><div id="wHEP3GWI10"><div class="AnswerExpandableOneState AnswerExpandable SimpleToggle Expandable Toggle" id="__w2_wHEP3GWI11__truncated"><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="wHEP3GWI20"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Spoilers galore ahead.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">1.) Varys is writing letters, presumably to the lords of the realm, informing them of Jon’s parentage.He’s toast for sure, quite literally. We meet a named “little bird”, Martha, who is apparently being watched by Daenerys’s soldiers. Why though? Varys tried to induct Jon into his band of traitors, but Jon stays steadfastly loyal to his queen.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">2.) Daenerys is surprisingly quick to catch on that she has been betrayed. Tyrion gives up Varys really fast. Why? To save Jon whom Daenerys suspects, or to ingratiate himself with the queen? Varys seems to expect his execution, a...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wHEP3GWI19_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" id="__w2_wHEP3GWI19_loading"><span class="loading">Loading…</span></span></div></div></div></div><div class="AnswerExpandableOneState AnswerExpandable SimpleToggle Expandable Toggle hidden" id="__w2_wp7E3K3z9_answer_content"><div id="wp7E3K3z10"><div class="AnswerExpandableOneState AnswerExpandable SimpleToggle Expandable Toggle" id="__w2_wp7E3K3z11__truncated"><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="wp7E3K3z20"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>SPOILER WARNING</b></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">…</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Despite people complaining about anything Game of Thrones related these days, I actually loved the episode.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">First of: <i>Dany</i>. I know that a bunch of people are blaming the show runners for ‘bad writing’ instead of blaming it on their imperceptive minds. That’s not supposed to be an insult, but the build up for an impulsive mother of dragons was there from season one. I’m not saying that this season isn’t generally rushed - it is. But the whole concept of Dany embracing her worst impulses has been there from the very beginning. The only difference now is that she has no one left...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wp7E3K3z19_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" One particular scene where a child watches a soldier kill a woman with his bare hands really shook me. There is no coming back from this for Dany!</li></ul><div class="ui_qtext_image_outer"><div class="ui_qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape ui_qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-679f9c2e57464619c88fcdafd5849890" master_src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-62feab3d34370e9c88f96d78284001a4" master_w="958" master_h="317"></div></div><ul><li>Cleganebowl! Incompetence on exhibition.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">For years I have been a huge fan of Game of Thrones. class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I actually really enjoyed this episode. Its the only one this season that kind of played out how things should have for me.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">The visual storytelling was excellent. The best part of the episode was watching Cersei’s demeanor slowly change from smug overconfidence to terror.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">This was done exceptionally well by only showing Drogon for the most part and not Dany.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">It was shown from multiple perspectives as well, and really drove the point home with the scenes of Arya running around on the ground experiencing the horror the civilians were experiencing. id="__w2_wo4xu2I99_answer_content"><div id="wo4xu2I913"><div class="Toggle SimpleToggle AnswerExpandable Expandable AnswerExpandableOneState" id="__w2_wo4xu2I914__truncated"><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="wo4xu2I920"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">A visual spectacle is a must for a big TV series. Hence dragons and what they can do must take centerstage otherwise many will fall to sleep watching people repeatedly trying to strangle each other over a throne episode after episode.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">In the other hand a mental spectacle is a must for any big novel series from which GoT is based. In novels readers are hooked either by the plot or by the ability of the author to convey what the characters are thinking. Since no one can really describe how dragons think most of the action are in the things that the characters think and do.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">S8E5 is a choice by t...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_wo4xu2I919_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" id="__w2_wo4xu2I919_loading"><span class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">It was an absolutely brilliant way to wrap up a large majority of the character arcs for one final showdown. For many of them they had reached the point of no return. Every action in Westeros has a consequence and be it it deeds done in pursuit of power, love, destiny or deeds done unto you, everything takes it’s toll and there could just not be a happy ending for these characters. Too much pain, too much guilt, too much determination. They teased it slightly in the last episode when Jamie left Brienne, Arya left Gendry to join Clegane, Grey Worm losing the only person who made him feel hum...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" dead, characterization has been evolved throughout the series and few became negative to positive and few positive to negative and Dany is one.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr All the earlier strategies suggested by Tyrion have failed miserably . Dany is having sense of insecurity. Dany has to win the King’s Landing by being “Cersei”, so she did it. I believe there was no other way , Cercei is way smarter than Dany and her team.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>Brothers farewell :</b></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Jamie and Tyrion’s farewell couldn’t have been better than this.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>Jon’s Obligation :</b></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Jon bent a knee to Dany as his queen so he cannot claim Iron throne till Dany is alive. id="w2dD6BhX27"></span></div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="__w2_w2dD6BhX29_suggested_section"></div></div></div><div id="__w2_w2dD6BhX9_answer_content"><div id="w2dD6BhX10"><div class="AnswerExpandable SimpleToggle Expandable Toggle AnswerExpandableOneState" id="__w2_w2dD6BhX11__truncated"><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="w2dD6BhX20"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">SPOILERS (duh)</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Probably the most disappointed I've ever been in a television episode. It's like they just chose to ignore 7 seasons of character development.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">First, when Dany chose to kill Varys. Now, this is in character for Dany, she is an insecure creature and prone to bad decisions like this. In her mind, Varys betrayed her by talking to Jon. But Jon just stood by and didn't say a word. Didn't try to talk her out of it. Is the Jon we know just going to let someone be killed for talking to him without even trying to save him?</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Second, when the dragon showed up and just started destroying wea...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_w2dD6BhX19_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span class="hidden" id="__w2_w2dD6BhX19_loading"><span class="loading">Loading…</span></span></div></div></div></div><div class="AnswerExpandable SimpleToggle Expandable Toggle AnswerExpandableOneState hidden" class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Though I liked the episode, since they ran ahead of the books (Seasons 7 and 8) they lost GRRM. Yes, he told them the ending and the major beats to get there, but he clearly hasn’t worked it all out himself or else we’d have the books. So the showrunners on their own, have basically rushed to the end and the motivations and complexity given to them in earlier seasons by the books are now absent. The dialogue isn’t as good either (Martin writes great dialogue). So it’s been disappointing, but we can see that the elements were all there to lead to the events of episode 5.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">As for Jamie and Only us. </i>Jaime Lannister</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>Spoilers for Episode 5 (Recap/Review)</b></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Episode 5 was much better than “The Last of the Starks.” The showrunners wanted to bring everything together in this episode.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">The bad news— that isn’t a high bar. This was a busy episode and very upsetting. I now do understand what GRRM means when he says that the showrunners will arrive at a similar ending. However, whatever we will get from the show will feel incomplete, even when we call it the end.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>Daenerys Lost Her Mind, But Why?</b> I expected class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div id="w413Byq520"></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">A possible outcome like this had been foreshadowed, but the sequence of events was very clumsily forced in the execution. I’m just hanging on for spectacle this last season or two. And I’m already all worn out on “Arya’s failed video game side quest” subplots from last time. And the “that stealth level that made me want to throw my PS2 off a balcony” subplot a couple weeks back. I get it, there’s no intrigue anymore, Littlefinger is dead, and it’s the Arya show now.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I just feel like the last few years, we’ve been watching a finely-crafted epic devolve into soapy CGI wharrgarbl in real time, ...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" id="__w2_w413Byq519_more"><span class="horizontal">(more)</span></a><span any TV series or movie, ever. The Queen we all believed will finally bring peace to Westeros with her rule, has indeed brought peace, but peace as a lack of people.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">She wanted to rule, and there she is, ruling the ashes of each person in King’s Landing. mad Queen was to be expected. She was always a mirror image of Cersei. The execution was bad and would have required more episodes to get right but if you think about it she had shown mad queen tendencies since the beginning but up until now always had advisers to turn her away from them. But with Jorah dead, Missandei (her best friend) dead, Jon following her as his queen but not his lover, Varys betraying her by trying to crown Jon, Sansa trying to crown Jon, Tyrion having doubts about her, another of her dragons dying what did you think was going to happen?</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I didn’t lik...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">What I liked:</p><ul><li>Hound’s death. I didn’t expect him to live too, the guys not afraid to die and his bro is now a zombie-ish super human so dying is the the best course for him.</li><li>Jaime and Cersei’s death. I also love how this ended. I like the idea that they were born together and they will die together. (Not only in this episode, after resurrection he is remarkably dumb.)</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">What’s wrong with Arya? class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">#####nice sgort the game of ^^^^^^^^</p><div class="ui_qtext_image_outer"><div class="ui_qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape ui_qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-aa22e829ddf067bd8553e09aaccf6abc" master_src="https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-5c2ab978a5179cdcd843ceca3123148f" master_w="1920" master_h="1080"></div></div><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">King’s Landing is dead, long live King’s Landing. Dany unleashing her inner Targaryen and turning the once resplendent capital of the Seven Kingdoms into the world’s largest KFC order was harrowing and horrifying yet entirely in tune with her character. She always has been a dormant volcano kept in check by those near and dear to her, and now that she has neither, well,<i> Vesuvius ain’t got shit on her.</i></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Yes, it was rushed and ill-executed, but the seeds were there. If only they had taken more time and allowed the turn to feel more organic.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">She is now official...</p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" sudden blindfolded because the show makers wanted him that way. He is lacking the power of logic and is a gullible guy. He was always a family man though.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Dany has been dealing with betrayal and bad luck for quite some time now from all corners. So her Targaryen blood just took over her otherwise benevolent soul (or was it a mask which fell off!).</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I felt strange today as I watched. class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>Can't believe I only just found this question. Loves me some idle speculation on one of my favorite things that absolutely does not matter (in the grand scheme of things).</b></p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>I like to break down my predictions on who will survive Game of Thrones into three categories, roughly falling into "characters likely to live," "characters likely to die," and "characters who I could go either way on." You could even include (and I will, for the purposes of this answer) characters who are alive at the end of Season 7 who we will very likely not see again in Season 8. So, let's get to it!</b></p><hr class="qtext_hr"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>CHARACTERS ALIVE A...</b></p></span><a class="ui_qtext_more_link" href="#" Tears of cersie, bravery of Jammie, the fight between mountain and hound and classy emotions of Jon Snow and Arya were too good.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Danny had gone mad once before and she did today. class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">The only action that surprised me tonight was Arya leaving King’s Landing. I was genuinely surprised (and happy) at the brokered peace between her &amp; the Hound.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">That and the fact that Cersei died too easily &amp; happily.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Dany turning insane? Foreshadowed well from the beginning. Her better angels were her advisors, and Varys was executed, Tyrion wasn’t trusted, Jorah died, Jon is scorned, and they were the only wise counsel keeping her from the brink. She followed exactly in her father’s footsteps and is not going to break the wheel, only adding another spoke. action_mousedown="QuestionLinkClickthrough" id="__w2_wGgA3irR36_link"><span class="ui_content_title unstyled_ui_title"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext">What's your review about Game of Thrones Season 8 Episode 5?</span></span></a></div></div><div class="ui_qtext_truncated ui_qtext_truncated_regular"><div class="ui_qtext_truncated_text"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Rushed but great.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Unexpected, as I expected it to be.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Highlight was the ‘Mad Queen’ theory coming true and the fact that it was not about Cersei.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">The destruction of the Iron Fleet and Qyburn’s scorpions along with Euron and Qyburn was exceptionally satisfying. I was literally praying for Drogons safety while he was lighting everything up.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Cersei and Jaime became a great story. They came in the world together, lived together, slept together and finally died together.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Tyrion is sad. Arya is mad. He won’t do much but I am so eager to see what Arya has in mind.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">And finally an end to house Clegane aft...</p></span><a ExpandedContent" id="__w2_w9Zr7tgP18_expanded_content"><div id="w9Zr7tgP20"></div><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div class="ui_qtext_expanded"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Once upon a time, my friend and I were talking about the greatest show ever made.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Eventually after a lot of self-musing it came down to two shows- Game of Thrones and Breaking Bad. Since S8 was yet to be released at that time we came to the conclusion that the final season of Got of Thrones would decide which show was better.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><b>Now that the first 5 episodes are out, without even watching the finale episode it has dawned upon us that Breaking Bad is the best series ever made.</b></p></span></div></div><div id="w9Zr7tgP28"><div class="ReadingContentFooter AnswerFooter ContentFooter" id="__w2_w9Zr7tgP29_content_footer"><span>350 views</span><span class="bullet"> · vu that we’re building up to this:</p><div class="ui_qtext_image_outer"><div class="ui_qtext_image_wrapper"><img class="landscape ui_qtext_image zoomable_in zoomable_in_feed" id="w2gLvsPH20"></div><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div class="ui_qtext_expanded"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Jon can’t get it up for Dany.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Dany loses her flipping mind and goes full-on Targaryen on Kings Landing. Burns the whole thing to the ground, (and probably accidentally burns a good number of her own troops in the process).</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Jon Snow still doesn’t know anything. Angry sex is the best sex, if he would have just fucked her right then and there, not only would he have saved thousands, but it would have been the best sex of his life!!</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">The end. (OH and they pretty much telegraphed that Arya will somehow take GreyWorms face or somebody and kill Dany. Jon takes the throne I guess. The end.)</p></span></div></div><div id="w2gLvsPH28"><div class="ReadingContentFooter AnswerFooter ContentFooter" id="__w2_w2gLvsPH29_content_footer"><span>946 views</span><span class="bullet"> · id="whrBD6og20"></div><div class="u-serif-font-main--regular"><div class="ui_qtext_expanded"><span class="ui_qtext_rendered_qtext"><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Dragons are just like footballplayers, one game they stink it up and disappear. Next game they are invincible and score at will.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">I liked the pace and the mass destruction. The golden company were not so golden, but rather pyrite nobodies.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">The hound went down in flames after the zombie mountain suddenly got sentient again.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start">Michael Bale upvoted this episode, but the readers of a song of fire and ice not so much.</p></span></div></div><div id="whrBD6og28"><div The Starbucks cup is evidence things became … sloppy.</p><p class="ui_qtext_para u-ltr u-text-align--start"><i>Would have preferred less dragon CGI,</i> less expensive effects and <i>more complex
